item.title: Ticket #960 (Alterations to plugins.php, themes.php, and wp-admin.css) updated
item.dc:creator: EricMeyer
item.description:
Er, the CSS is supposed to read:

.active td {background: BEB;} .active .name {background: 9C9;} .active.alternate td {background: ADA;} .active.alternate .name {background: 8B8;}

...with an octothorpe (#) before each of the values. Apparently the mozquito script decided I was trying to post bug references instead of shorthand hex. Or something.

item.title: Ticket #961 (links from get_links() not html compatible) updated
item.dc:creator: senilix
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #961 (links from get_links() not html compatible) created
item.dc:creator: senilix
item.description:
Links from get_links() should be escaped with htmlentities(). I modified wp-content/plugins/authimage.php to this:

if (($row->link_url != null) && ($row->link_url != )) {

$the_link = $row->link_url;

} $the_link = htmlentities($the_link);

item.title: Ticket #960 (Alterations to plugins.php, themes.php, and wp-admin.css) updated
item.dc:creator: EricMeyer
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #960 (Alterations to plugins.php, themes.php, and wp-admin.css) created
item.dc:creator: EricMeyer
item.description:
With some minor alterations, it's possible to enhance the display of plugin and theme tables simply by adding 'active' to the table-row class of any theme or plugin that's currently active. Here's the modified PHP to do it in plugins.php:

<?php

$style = ; foreach($plugins as $plugin_file => $plugin_data) {

$style = ('class="alternate"' == $style
'class="alternate active"' == $style) ? : 'alternate';

if (!empty($current_plugins) && in_array($plugin_file, $current_plugins)) {

$action = "<a href='plugins.php?action=deactivate&plugin=$plugin_file' title='".('Deactivate this plugin')."' class='delete'>".('Deactivate')."</a>"; $plugin_dataTitle? = "<strong>{$plugin_dataTitle?}</strong>"; $style .= $style == 'alternate' ? ' active' : 'active';

} else {

$action = "<a href='plugins.php?action=activate&plugin=$plugin_file' title='".('Activate this plugin')."' class='edit'>".('Activate')."</a>";

} $plugin_dataDescription? = wp_kses($plugin_dataDescription?, array('a' => array('href' => array(),'title' => array()),'abbr' => array('title' => array()),'acronym' => array('title' => array()),'code' => array(),'em' => array(),'strong' => array()) ); ; if ($style != ) $style = 'class="' . $style . '"'; echo "

<tr $style>

<td class=\"name\">{$plugin_dataTitle?}</td> <td class=\"vers\">{$plugin_dataVersion?}</td> <td class=\"auth\">{$plugin_dataAuthor?}</td> <td class=\"desc\">{$plugin_dataDescription?}</td> <td class=\"togl\">$action</td>

</tr>"; }

?>

Here it is for themes.php:

<?php

$style = ;

$theme_names = array_keys($themes); natcasesort($theme_names);

foreach ($theme_names as $theme_name) {

$template = $themes[$theme_name]Template?; $stylesheet = $themes[$theme_name]Stylesheet?; $title = $themes[$theme_name]Title?; $version = $themes[$theme_name]Version?; $description = $themes[$theme_name]Description?; $author = $themes[$theme_name]Author?;

if ($template == $current_template && $stylesheet == $current_stylesheet) {

$action = '<strong>' . ('Active Theme') . '</strong>'; $current = true;

} else {

$action = "<a href='themes.php?action=activate&template=$template&stylesheet=$stylesheet' title='" . ('Select this theme') . "' class='edit'>" . ('Select') . '</a>'; $current = false;

}

$style = ('class="alternate"' == $style
'class="alternate active"' == $style) ? : 'alternate';

if ($current) $style .= $style == 'alternate' ? ' active' : 'active'; if ($style != ) $style = 'class="' . $style . '"';

echo "

<tr $style>";

if ( $current )

echo "<td><strong>$title $version</strong></td>";

else

echo "<td>$title $version</td>";

echo "

<td class=\"auth\">$author</td> <td class=\"desc\">$description</td> <td class=\"togl\">$action</td>

</tr>";

}

?>

And the CSS that would green-ify any active plugin or theme:

.active td {background: #BEB;} .active .name {background: #9C9;} .active.alternate td {background: #ADA;} .active.alternate .name {background: #8B8;}

item.title: Ticket #959 (trackback_rdf is only called in index.php, not single.php) updated
item.dc:creator: gbhugo
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #959 (trackback_rdf is only called in index.php, not single.php) created
item.dc:creator: gbhugo
item.description:
Trackback autodiscovery uses the tracback_RDF stuff to find the trackback URI. The problem with WordPress is: the tracback_RDF call is in the index.php template file, not in the single.php file. Clients that link to a specific URI will fetch that URI and search for the RDF snippet. If there are more than one snippet, they will use the one with the matching URI in the RDF snippet. So the trackback_RDF call in index.php doesn't help with article trackbacks, as those will go against the single posting page and use single.php. And the trackback_RDF call in index.php doesn't help at all, because if somebody links to some archive page of a month or the main index page, the trackback_RDF snippets still contain the postings permalinks and so don't match.

I'd say throw out the call from the index.php and archive.php and put it into the single.php template file.

item.title: Ticket #958 (Comment feed for a single post shows only first 10 comments) updated
item.dc:creator: ringmaster
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #958 (Comment feed for a single post shows only first 10 comments) updated
item.dc:creator: ringmaster
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #958 (Comment feed for a single post shows only first 10 comments) created
item.dc:creator: ringmaster
item.description: When generating the comments RSS feed for a single post, WordPress selects comments in ascending order rather than descending order. The result is that after the maximum number of comments have been added to a post (as set in preferences), new comments do not appear in the feed.

item.title: Ticket #957 (Plugin Editor messes up entities) updated
item.dc:creator: MaThIbUs
item.description: Alright, the entity should be & # 1 8 2 ; Just download the file.

item.title: Ticket #957 (Plugin Editor messes up entities) updated
item.dc:creator: MaThIbUs
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #957 (Plugin Editor messes up entities) created
item.dc:creator: MaThIbUs
item.description:
Create a file called whatever.php, with the following contents (or just download the attachment):

<?php /* Plugin Name: Some Plugin Version: 1.0 Plugin URI: ​http://example.com/ Description: The Plugin Editor messes with my entities. Author: Mathias Bynens Author URI: ​http://mathibus.com/ */

$entity = "¶"; or whatever entity here

?>

and upload it in the wp-content/plugins/ directory. Alternatively, you could add the $entity = "¶"; line to any existing plugin you have, just to test. After you've done this, go to the plugin editor, and edit the file you just uploaded / the plugin you just modified. Look for the line with the entity --- it's translated into its character. Bad, WP, bad.

item.title: Ticket #953 (A theme whose name contains ' cannot be edited using the built-in editor) updated
item.dc:creator: Waldo
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #953 (A theme whose name contains ' cannot be edited using the built-in editor) created
item.dc:creator: Waldo
item.description:
If you define a theme whose name contains an apostrophe, that theme cannot be edited within the admin interface. Instead, a nice little error about how the file doesn't exist gets thrown. The base reason for this lies in <wp-admin/theme-editor.php>, just below the line containing '<select name="theme" id="theme">'. The problem is that the theme name is not HTML-escaped, but the option value is wrapped in apostrophes.

I discovered this bug when attempting to define a theme with the name "Where's Waldo?" (without the enclosing double quotes).

This seems trivial to patch, but simply escaping using htmlspecialchars() with ENT_QUOTES doesn't quite seem to work -- I need to dig in a little further first to figure out what's not happening that should. I promise I'll do some more testing, but it'll have to wait for now. (It's also rather trivial to work around by using a different name -- it doesn't seem to appear in any user-facing areas, so it's a mostly cosmetic issue.)

item.title: Ticket #952 (cruftfree URLs based on ErrorDocument don't work right on some servers) updated
item.dc:creator: gbhugo
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #952 (cruftfree URLs based on ErrorDocument don't work right on some servers) created
item.dc:creator: gbhugo
item.description: When using lighttpd and the ErrorDocument method of working cruft free URIs, the Statuscode is still 404 when returning the content. This can be circumvented by explicitely setting the status to 200 on success. A patch is in the attached note.

mysql> SELECT comment_type FROM wp_comments ORDER BY comment_ID DESC LIMIT 5; +--------------+ | comment_type | +--------------+ | | | | | | | | | | +--------------+ 5 rows in set (0.00 sec)

mysql>

item.title: Ticket #946 (comment moderation requests for entries with comments disabled) updated
item.dc:creator: JasonV
item.description:
SELECT comment_type FROM wp_comments ORDER BY comment_ID DESC LIMIT 5

That should give you the comment type for the five most recent comments/pings. (If you changed the table prefix in wp-config.php, then make sure you change "wp_" above.)

Status changed

Are you certain these are not trackbacks? Trackbacks can be held for moderation just like comments, and will look the same.

This is still confusing, though... perhaps the issue is this: should trackbacks be clearly marked as such in the admin UI/notification emails/etc.?

item.title: Ticket #946 (comment moderation requests for entries with comments disabled) updated
item.dc:creator: dmd
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #946 (comment moderation requests for entries with comments disabled) created
item.dc:creator: dmd
item.description:
I get a few dozen "comment waiting for your approval" messages per day on comments which have comments turned off. All of these messages are for comments from spammers (mostly texas hold-em poker).

This is occuring even though comments are OFF for ALL entries. Not just off as in comments are turned off for future posts, but off as in I have verified that each individual entry (there's only five of them, so it's not difficult to check) has comments off. The entries say "comments off" in the blog's web page, and the checkbox for comments is unchecked for each of them - and yet every day I get more moderation requests for them.

Several other people are having this issue as well: see ​http://wordpress.org/support/topic.php?id=24313

item.title: Ticket #945 (pingback is always sent) updated
item.dc:creator: bronski
item.description:
A bit more information:

  • checking the option sets option_value to '1', unchchecking it to .
  • pingback is sent in both cases.
  • this is tested locally by linking to my own blog and linking to other blogs. option_value was set to but pingback was sent.
  • there are two places in post.php where pingback happens: in action-case 'post' and 'edit'.
  • in case 'edit' I added an error_log() which always wrote to the logfile, regardless of the setting in option_value. (but pingback was not sent, I guess because it was sent when being published?! the ping site is not in field 'pinged' table posts though...)
  • after adding " === '1'" to the if's logging and pinging stopped.

item.title: Ticket #945 (pingback is always sent) updated
item.dc:creator: bronski
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #945 (pingback is always sent) created
item.dc:creator: bronski
item.description: Regardless of discussion-option "Attempt to notify [...]" links in entries always get pinged. I tried to fix this by making sure the option_value for default_pingback_flag really is '1' and not empty.
